Since my first day in Congress, I have made it clear that I will fight any and every effort that threatens Nevadans’ access to quality, affordable health care, and I will not stop now.

We are talking about the very real consequences people face if Congress refuses to act. Every American and most members of Congress agree that we need to do something about the skyrocketing cost of prescription drugs.
That’s not a choice that any person, or family, should have to make in this country. That’s why we are fighting so hard to lower drug prices and protect the #AffordableCareAct from being torn apart.

… and now they have to make the choice between getting their medicine and buying groceries, fixing their car, or paying rent on time. Last year, one in three Americans did not fill a prescription due to high prices.
Nearly every week, I hear from my constituents about how the price of their insulin, their heart medication, or their kid’s inhaler jumped 50, 75, and sometimes over 100 percent …
There are very few issues in our state and country that are as important as making health care more affordable and accessible - especially when it comes to lowering the cost of prescription drugs.
I had a roundtable discussion w/ @RepHorsford @YvannaCancela @HCAN @BattleBornProg on what we need to do to reduce prescription drug prices and protect the #ACA. pic.twitter.com/1ScSi5tOY2

The bottom line is we need Congress and every elected official to commit to our communities and to the American people, not to special interests.

Opioid abuse doesn’t care if you live in a red state or a blue state or a purple state, and addiction does not care about the D or R next to your name ... It’s immune to partisanship and socioeconomic status.

Well, I did something about it to get the ball rolling in Congress. The House passed my bill to increase funding for the Drug-Free Communities Program, which directly invests in local community efforts to combat opioid abuse.

There are a number of ways to prevent and reduce opioid abuse, addiction, and death. The problem is that our communities--like southern Nevada and our rural communities—just don’t have the resources or the funding to implement the solutions that we know work.

Opioid addiction is hitting our veteran population harder than any other, and it’s largely because of how our country has decided to treat them--by throwing prescription painkiller after prescription painkiller at them rather than giving them comprehensive medical treatment.
At least one Nevadan loses their life to opioids every day, & that’s especially painful b/c we know it’s preventable. And for no group of people is that more true than for our veterans.
We must treat opioid addiction like the public health crisis that it is. It is now the leading cause of accidental deaths in the US.
I’m about to speak at the 2019 Opioid Abuse Prevention Summit, hosted by @NVPublicHealth. Stay tuned for live updates on what we need to do to tackle this epidemic. pic.twitter.com/kKU6NhKj8g
